captions.text:
JAMES GRIME: OK, so,
the superflip--

so let me write down the
superflip for you.

Rubik's cube fans have a
notation, and they call this

the up, they call this the
down, they call this the

for obvious reasons-- the
left-hand side, the front,

and the back, which is facing
away from me there.

So it's got up, down, left,
right, front, and back.

I can write down the superflip
using this idea.

I'm going to write down what the
20 moves are, then we'll

So I'm going to turn
the up once.

Now, this means right-hand
side twice--
Oh, one, two that one too.

"U" dash-- that means the
opposite direction--

And then do the front twice,
so once, twice.

So there are 20 moves
there, and this was

From the solved state, you get
this really pretty combination

there, and this is the furthest
away from being

Now, if you look at it, what's
happened is all the corners

You see, this is the
orange face.

All the orange corners and
the center are just fine.

This is the orange-white edge,
and it's flipped over.

This is the orange-blue edge,
and it's flipped over.

This is the orange-yellow edge,
which is flipped over.

And that's the orange-green
edge, and that's flipped over.

So all the edge pieces
flip over.

All the corners are absolutely
fine, and the centers are

There's a couple of cool things
about this superflip
that I haven't told you yet.

So if I do the superflip
twice--

If I do it twice, I will get
back to where I started.

In mathematics, we say
it has order 2.

You do it twice, and you'll get
back to where you started.

The other cool thing about the
superflip is that if I do a

bunch of moves, and then I do
the superflip, you'll get the

same answer as if you do the
superflip first, and then you
So you'll get the same answer.

So if you do superflip first,
and stuff, or if you do stuff

first, and superflip, you'll get
the exact same position.

In fact, superflip is the only
move that isn't just doing

It's the only move that
has that property.

MALE SPEAKER: Because I would
have thought that would be

true for everything,
but it's not.

JAMES GRIME: It's not
true for everything.

So if I do a move followed
by another

You get a different answer if
you do it in a different

order, if you swap those over,
except for the superflip.

comments.text:
When he says "a bunch of moves", he means ANY bunch of moves. The U perm 
doesn't have the same property he's talking about, since if the "bunch of 
moves" affect any of the 3 edges the U perm cycle, it won't be true that U 
perm + "bunch of moves" = "bunch of moves" + U perm.  The superflip on the 
other hand works no matter what "bunch of moves" you choose.

comments.text:
Another way to superflip your cube is to solve it using the beginner's 
method, except purposely making all the second layer edge pieces flipped in 
the right place, continue solving as normal, flip the edges to the right 
position, and the top layer should now be superflipped. Now flip the cube 
upside down and flip the edges once more. The cube is now superflipped. How 
many times did I say flip?﻿

comments.author: Malik Glossop

comments.text:
Many things about what you say are wrong. He never said that the superflip 
was the only algorithm that did that. He said that the superflip is the 
only algorithm where Superflip + [stuff] = [stuff] + superflip for all 
[stuff].

The second thing you said is wrong too. The number of repetitions it takes 
to return to your initial state has nothing to do with the length of the 
algorithm. The number of repetitions it takes is always the least common 
multiple of the number of elements in each cycle in the algorithm.

comments.author: EpicPowered

comments.text: Ah, I see. Thanks for the explanation!
comments.author: Stephan Muller

comments.text:
What he means is that, mathematically, the superflip is the only non 
trivial commutative element (commutative means you can switch position with 
any other element, e.g. 1+2=2+1). The trivial one is the 0 element, which 
for the rubik's cube is doing nothing (for this one, it's obvious, since 
you can do nothing before your move or after your move as much as you like 
without changing the outcome).
While there may be patterns you can find that end up the same (easiest 
example is turning completely unrelated sides like front and back), the 
superflip is the only one that ends up the same for every single move you 
pair it with, without exception.
Everything else you can find that seems like that will either A: end up 
with at least one case where it doesn't work, B: is based on essentially 
doing nothing (e.g. turning a side 4 times, which is mathematically 
considered the same as doing nothing, aka 0), or C: is another version of 
doing the superflip. These are the only 3 possibilities.

comments.author: Matt Hilbert

comments.text:
It's not that any other solution is less than twenty moves away, but it 
does take a claravoyant to "see" a path to solution in the ordered mess of 
colors and positions. some fixes for the cube are patterned moves which 
solve definative aspects of the cube, while finding a solution for the 
random + the superflip would be a matter of decoding and fact-finding, for 
which, in terms of a solution based on a time limit, could take longer than 
outright progressive re-build of the faces. "20" steps is not a benchmark 
for solving the cube, it is quite likely that getting it to that point may 
take 10, 15, or even 30 steps alone. The superflip simply takes a solved 
cube and puts it into a position RELATIVE to it original position. It is 
sorta like zero, twice nothing is still nothing. So, you try to solve for 
zero. Find the state relative to zero and you have solved the puzzle.﻿

new superflip algorithm?
comments.author: foxys2100

comments.text:
Well, essentially what you're doing is doing the super flip twice. The 
super flip will flip the edges. Solving it will flip the edges back. If you 
do the same moveset stating from a solved cube, you would flip the edges. 
Then doing the superflip would flip them back,

Why can I reply to You but NO ONE else?

Anyways Alcesmire, Do they have the God's Number and the Unit Orbit (in 
this case Superflip on 3-cube*) for NxNxN cubes yet?

Are cubes that are of Even N have vastly different properties?

And HOW friggan awesome would it be to play GO or Chess on  19x19x19 or 
4x4x4 (64 squares like chess) 0r 8x8x8 (same layout)?

What about Halma or Chinese Checkers (which itself has 121, 181 and 257 
board-size variants)? ;) Endless amazing possibilities.  These are the 
things we will create to placate Superbeings post-Singularity. I can 
Guarantee it.

*Forgive the new notation. I was trying to be succinct and cool and smart 
at the same time. A truly difficult task, one that hasn't been yet mastered 
even by the geniuses that cracked the Rubik's Cube.

comments.author: PeruibeGaming

comments.text:
His main field of studies is based around combinatorics and permutations. 
And these kind of extreme cases are among the most interesting things to 
study. Of course he's excited about it. The problem has really exciting 
symmetries in it's permutations, but I suppose you have to be somewhat 
knowledgeable about the math regarding it to really appreciate it. You 
don't think the facts that any cube can be solved in 20 steps or fewer and 
that this is the only 20 step arrangement are interesting?
comments.author: Alcesmire

comments.text:
It has to do with the fact that the amount of moves required to generate 
the Superflip is 20. That's the maximum number of moves required to solve 
any Rubik's Cube, a.k.a. God's number. Every other configuration of a 
Rubik's Cube can be solved in less than twenty moves, so they are "closer" 
to the solved state than the Superflip.

comments.author: Ethan Davies

comments.text:
It takes 20 or more moves to solve the Rubik's Cube from the superflip. You 
can't solve it in 19 moves. It has been proven that the minimum amount of 
moves required to solve a Rubik's cube from any position is never more than 
20.

comments.text:
This video and others in the series convinced me to buy a Rubik's cube. 
After having one as a child and being endlessly frustrated I'm happy to 
finally be unlocking the secrets. I figure I will learn the methods first 
and let the principles unfold then I'll start puzzling over the math. 
Thanks for including the Superflip notation & reminding me to follow Dr. 
Grimes on Twitter. I came back just to make sure I was using the same 
notation as numberphile. It's much better than the one I made up.

comments.author: GolldenFalcon

comments.text:
I consider myself quite the nerd, but I've never understood the fascination 
with cubing. It's a solved puzzle. Most people don't figure them out 
anymore, they simply repeat algorithms. A puzzle is something to logic your 
way through, but once the strategy is known, solving a cube (or any other 
shape for that matter) is trivially easy. It strikes me as a complicated 
Tic-Tac-Toe; it's got its use teaching game theory and AI, but why-oh-why 
are you guys drawn to such a pastime?
comments.author: Sami Elahmadie

yes cubing really is a thing ... unless you are involved with twisty 
puzzles, people have no idea how extensive the community really is. there 
are hundreds of competitions, with many different classes (2x2-5x5, blind 
solving, one hand, feet, multi-blind...) each year all leading up to world 
championships held in Las Vegas.
